If the Forest Settlement-officer admits in whole or in part any claim under section 12, he shall also record the extent to which the claim is so admitted, specifying the number and description of the cattle which the claimant is from time to time entitled to graze in the forest, the season during which such pasture is permitted, the quantity of timber and other forest-produce which he is from time to time authorized to take or receive, and such other particulars as the case may require. He shall also record whether the timber or other forest-produce obtained by the exercise of the rights claimed may be sold or bartered.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Exercise of rights admitted</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">15. (1) After making such record the Forest Settlement-officer shall, to the best of his ability, and having due regard to the maintenance of the reserved forest in respect of which the claim is made, pass such orders as will ensure the continued exercise of the rights so admitted.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) For this purpose the Forest Settlement-officer may-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) set out some other forest-tract of sufficient extent, and in a locality reasonably convenient, for the purposes of such claimants, and record an order conferring upon them a right of pasture or to forest-produce (as the case may be) to the extent so admitted; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) so alter the limits of the proposed forest as to exclude forest-land of sufficient extent, and in a locality reasonably convenient, for the purposes of the claimants; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) record an order, continuing to such claimants a right of pasture or to forest-produce, as the case may be, to the extent so admitted, as such seasons, within such portions of the proposed forest, and under such rules, as may be made in this behalf by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Commutation of rights</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">16. In case the Forest Settlement-officer finds it impossible, having due regard to the maintenance of the reserved forest, to make such settlement under section 15 as shall ensure the continued exercise of the said rights to the extent so admitted, he shall, subject to such rules as the Government may make in this behalf, commute such rights, by the payment to such persons of a sum of money in lieu thereof, or by the grant of land, or in such other manner as he thinks fit.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Time limit for resolution of claims</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">10[ 16A. (1) Within 12 months after the period fixed under section 6 has elapsed, or within 12 months after the enactment of this section, whichever is later, the Forest Settlement Officer shall do one of the following:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) dispose of all claims made under sections 6 and 9; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii) obtain an extension of this 12 months deadline under sub-section (2).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Upon application of a Forest Settlement Officer, the Deputy Commissioner may grant a single 2 months extension of the deadline in sub-section (1), making the deadline 14 months, and if that extended deadline threatens to be missed, the Commissioner may grant additional 4 months extensions.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Appeal from order passed under section 11, section 12, section 15 or section 16</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">11[ 17. Any person who has made a claim under this Act, or any Forest-officer or other person generally or specially empowered by the Government in this behalf, may, within three months from the date of the order passed on such claim by the Forest Settlement-officer under section 11, section 12, section 15 or section 16, present an appeal from such order to the Divisional Commissioner concerned.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Appeal under section 17</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">18.(1) [Omitted by section 3 of the Forest (Amendment) Act, 2000 (Act No. X of 2000).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">12[ (2)(a) An appeal shall be heard by the Divisional Commissioner in the manner prescribed for the time being for the hearing of appeals in matters relating to land-development tax and the appeal shall be disposed of within 6 months from the date of presenting it under section 17.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) The Divisional Commissioner shall report to the Government the particulars of the cases which could not be disposed by him within the time prescribed in clause (a), where upon the Government may extend time as deemed necessary.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The order passed on the appeal by the Divisional Commissioner shall, subject only to revision by the Government, be final.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Pleaders</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">19. The Government, or any person who has made a claim under this Act, may appoint any person to appear, plead and act</p><p style="text-align: justify;">on its or his behalf before the Forest Settlement-officer, or 13[ the Divisional Commissioner], in the course of any inquiry or appeal under this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Notification declaring forest reserved</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">20. (1) When the following events have occurred, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) the period fixed under section 6 for preferring claims has elapsed, and all claims, if any, made under that section or section 9 have been disposed of by the Forest Settlement-officer;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) if any such claims have been made, the period limited by section 17 for appealing from the orders passed on such claims has elapsed, and all appeals (if any) presented within such period have been disposed of by the 14[ Divisional Commissioner]; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) all lands (if any) to be included in the proposed forest, which the Forest Settlement-officer has, under section 11, elected to acquire under the 15[ Acquisition and Requisition of Immovable Property Ordinance, 1982 (II of 1982), have become vested in the Government under section 11 of that Ordinance],</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the Government shall publish a notification in the official Gazette, specifying definitely, according to boundary-marks erected or otherwise, the limits of the forest which is to be reserved, and declaring the same to be reserved from a date fixed by the notification.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) From the date so fixed such forest shall be deemed to be a reserved forest.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Publication of translation of such notification in neighbourhood of forest</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">21. The Forest-officer shall, before the date fixed by such notification, 16[ cause it] to be published in every town and village in the neighbourhood of the forest.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to revise arrangement made under section 15 or section 18</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">22. The Government may, within five years from the publication of any notification under section 20, revise any arrangement made under section 15 or section 18, and may for this purpose rescind or modify any order made under section 15 or section 18, and direct that any one of the proceedings specified in section 15 be taken in lieu of any other of such proceedings, or that the rights admitted under section 12 be commuted under section 16.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>No right acquired over reserved forest, except as here provided</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">23. No right of any description shall be acquired in or over a reserved forest except by succession or under a grant or contract in writing made by or on behalf of the Government or some person in whom such right was vested when the notification under section 20 was issued.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Rights not to be alienated without sanction</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">24. (1) Notwithstanding anything contained in section 23, no right continued under clause (c) of sub-section (2) of section 15 shall be alienated by way of grant, sale, lease, mortgage or otherwise, without the sanction of the Government:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that, when any such right is appendant to any land or house, it may be sold or otherwise alienated with such land or house.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) No timber or other forest-produce obtained in exercise of any such right shall be sold or bartered except to such extent as may have been admitted in the order recorded under section 14.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to stop ways and water-courses in reserved forests</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">25. The Forest-officer may, with the previous sanction of the Government or of any officer duly authorized by it in this behalf, stop any public or private way or water-course in a reserved forest, provided that a substitute for the way or water-course so stopped, which the Government deems to be reasonably convenient, already exists, or has been provided or constructed by the Forest-officer in lieu thereof.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Acts prohibited in such forests</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">26. 17[ (1) Any person who, in a reserved forest-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) kindles, keeps or carries any fire except at such seasons as the Forest-Officer may notify in this behalf.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) trespasses or pastures cattle, or permits cattle to trespass;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) causes any damage by negligence in felling any tree or cutting or dragging any timber;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) quarries stone, burns lime or charcoal, or collects, subjects to any manufacturing process, or removes, any forest produce other than timber;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">or who enters a reserved forest with fire arms without prior permission from the Divisional Forest Officer concerned, shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months and shall also be liable to fine which may extend to two thousand Taka, in addition to such compensation for damage done to the forest as the convicting Court may direct to be paid.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(1A) Any person who-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) makes any fresh clearing prohibited by section 5; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) removes any timber from a reserved forest; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) sets fire to a reserved forest, or, in contravention of any rules made by the Government in this behalf, kindles any fire, or leaves any fire burning, in such manner as to endanger such a forest;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">or who, in a reserved forest</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) fells, girdles, lops, taps or burns any tree or strips off the bark or leaves from or otherwise damages, the same;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) clears or breaks up any land for cultivation or any other purpose 18[ or cultivates or attempts to cultivate any land in any other manner];</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) in contravention of any rules made in this behalf by the Government, hunts, shoots, fishes, poisons water or sets traps or snares; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g) establishes saw-pits or saw-benches or converts trees into timber without lawful authority,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to five years and shall not be less than six months, and shall also be liable to fine which may extend to fifty thousand Taka and shall not be less than five thousand Taka, in addition to such compensation for damage done to the forest as the convicting Court may direct to be paid.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Nothing in this section shall be deemed to prohibit?</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) any act done by permission in writing of the Forest-officer, or under any rule made by the Government; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) the exercise of any right continued under clause (c) of sub-section (2) of section 15, or created by grant or contract in writing made by or on behalf of the Government under section 23.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Whenever fire is caused wilfully or by gross negligence in a reserved forest, the Government may (notwithstanding that any penalty has been inflicted under this section) direct that in such forest or any portion thereof the exercise of all rights of pasture or to forest-produce shall be suspended for such period as it thinks fit.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to declare forest no longer reserved</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">27. (1) The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, direct that, from a date fixed by such notification, any forest or any portion thereof reserved under this Act shall cease to be a reserved forest.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) From the date so fixed, such forest or portion shall cease to be reserved; but the rights (if any) which have been extinguished therein shall not revive in consequence of such cessation.</p><p align="center">CHAPTER III</p><p align="center">19 OF VILLAGE-FORESTS AND SOCIAL FORESTRY</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Formation of village forests</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">28. (1) The Government may assign to any village community the rights of Government to or over any land which has been constituted a reserved forest, and may cancel such assignment. All forests so assigned shall be called village forests.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Government may make rules for regulating the management of village-forests, prescribing the conditions under which the community to which any such assignment is made may be provided with timber or other forest-produce or pasture, and their duties for the protection and improvement of such forest.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) All the provisions of this Act relating to reserved forests shall (so far as they are not inconsistent with the rules so made) apply to village-forests.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Social Forestry</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">20[ 28A. (1) On any land which is the property of the Government or over which the Government has proprietory rights, and on any other land assigned to the Government by voluntary written agreement of the owner for the purpose of afforestation, conservation or management through social forestry, the Government may establish a social forestry programme under sub-section (2).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) A social Forestry programme is established when the Government by one or more written agreements assigns rights to forest-produce or rights to use the land, for the purposes of social forestry, to person assisting the Government in management of the land.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Notwithstanding any other provision of law, agreements under sub-section (2) concerning Government-owned lands need not be registered in the local records of right to lands, and no party to such an unregistered agreement</p><p style="text-align: justify;">may be divested of rights solely by execution of a subsequent assignment of rights by the Government to another person.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The Government may make rules to set out standards for social forestry agreements and programme, and such standards shall at a minimum-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) require agreements to include or make reference to an agreed-upon management plant for the social forestry programme;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii) guarantee participants an equitable share of proceeds in return for labour invested;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(iii) in the case of agreements contemplating timber harvest, require the duration of agreements to include the expected principal harvest;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(iv) allow transfer of benefits and obligations under agreements between spouses, and, when a participant dies, under the laws of succession to his heir, and govern other transfers;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(v) allow creation and dissolution of management committees representing participants in particular programmes, and empower the management committees to impose fine on participants for violation of agreement; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(vi) allow persons to petition the Government for 'undertaking' social forestry programme.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) The Government may make rules to set out other requirements or guarantees for agreements, including</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) duties of participants to assist forest officers; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii) any other matter concerning formation or operation of social forestry programmes.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(6) Rules made under this section may recognize different classes of social forestry programmes, and the Government may make different rules for different classes or programmes.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(7) The Government may publish guidelines and forms for social forestry agreements.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Effect of other of law on social forestry</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">28B. (1) For the purposes of section 26 and 34, the exercise of any right granted by a social forestry agreement under section 28A shall be considered to be done with permission in writing of the Forest-Officer.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Section 80 shall not apply to private lands subject to a voluntary written agreement under section 28A, unless such agreement itself allows the Government to invoke all or part of section 80.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Section 81 shall not apply to participants in social forestry projects under section 28A.]</p><p align="center">CHAPTER IV</p><p align="center">OF PROTECTED FORESTS</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Protected forests</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">29. (1) The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, declare the provisions of this Chapter applicable to any forest-land or waste-land which is not included in a reserved forest, but which is the property of Government, or over which the Government has proprietary rights, or to the whole or any part of the forest -produce of which the Government is entitled.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The forest-land and waste-lands comprised in any such notification shall be called a "protected forest".</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) No such notification shall be made unless the nature and extent of the rights of Government and of private persons in or over the forest-land or waste-land 21[ or charland] comprised therein have been inquired into and recorded at a survey or settlement, or in such other manner as the Government thinks sufficient. Every such record shall be presumed to be correct until the contrary is proved:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that, if, in the case of any forest-land or waste-land, 22[ or charland] the Government thinks that such inquiry and record are necessary, but that they will occupy such length of time as in the meantime to endanger the rights of Government, the Government may, pending such inquiry and record, declare such land to be a protected forest, but so as not to abridge or affect any existing rights of individuals or communities.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to issue notification reserving trees, etc</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">30. The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) declare any trees or class of trees in a protected forest to be reserved from a date fixed by the notification;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) declare that any portion of such forest specified in the notification shall be closed for such term, not exceeding thirty years, as the Government thinks fit, and that the rights of private persons, if any, over such portion shall be suspended during such term, provided that the remainder of such forest be sufficient, and in locality reasonably convenient, for the due exercise of the rights suspended in the portion so closed; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) prohibit, from a date fixed as aforesaid, the quarrying of stone, or the burning of lime or charcoal, or the collection or subjection to any manufacturing process, or removal of, any forest-produce in any such forest, and the 23[ breaking up, clearing or use] for cultivation, for building, for herding cattle or for any other purpose, of any land in any such forest.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Publication of translation of such notification in neighbourhood</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">31. The Collector shall cause a translation into 24[ Bengali] of every notification issued under section 30 to be affixed in a conspicuous place in every town and village in the neighbourhood of the forest comprised in the notification.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to make rules for protected forests</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">32. The Government may make rules to regulate the following matters, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) the cutting, sawing, conversion and removal of trees and timber, and the collection, manufacture and removal of forest-produce, from protected forests;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) the grating of licences to the inhabitants of towns and villages in the vicinity of protected forests to take trees, timber or other forest-produce for their own use, and the production and return of such licences by such persons;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) the granting of licences to persons felling or removing trees or timber or other forest-produce from such forests for the purposes of trade, and the production and return of such licences by such persons;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) the payments, if any, to be made by the persons mentioned in clauses (b) and (c) for permission to cut such trees, or to collect and remove such timber or other forest-produce;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) the other payments, if any, to be made by them in respect of such trees, timber and produce, and the places where such payment shall be made;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) the examination of forest-produce passing out of such forests;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g) the clearing and breaking up of land for cultivation or other purposes in such forests;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h) the protection from fire of timber lying in such forests and of trees reserved under section 30;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) the cutting of grass and pasturing of cattle in such forests;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(j) hunting, shooting, fishing, poisoning water and setting traps or snares in such forests, 25[ * * *];</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(k) the protection and management of any portion of a forest closed under section 30; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(l) the exercise of rights referred to in section 29.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Penalties for acts in contravention of 26[ section 28A or of] notification under section 30 or of rules under section 32</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">33. 27[ (1) Any person who commits any of the following offences, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) contrary to any prohibition under section 30, quarries any stone, or burns any lime or charcoal,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">or collects, subjects to any manufacturing process, or removes any forest produce other than timber;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) leaves burning any fire kindled by him in the vicinity of any protected forest;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) causes any damage by negligence in felling any tree or cutting or dragging any timber;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) trespasses or pastures cattle, or permits cattle to trespass;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) enters a protected forest with fire arms without prior permission from the Divisional Forest Officer concerned;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) infringes any rule made under section 32 28[ ;]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">29[ (g) any offence or damage committed against social forestry programme will be deemed as an offense,]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months and shall also be liable to fine which may extend to two thousand Taka, in addition such compensation for damage done to the forest as the convicting court may direct to be paid.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>(1A) Any person who commits any of the following offences, namely:</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) sets fire to a protected forest or, in contravention of any rules made by the Government in this behalf, kindles any fire, or leaves any fire burning, in such manner as to endanger such a forest;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) fells, girdles, lops, taps or burns any tree reserved under section 30, or strips off the bark or leaves from, or otherwise damages, any such tree;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) contrary to any prohibition under section 30, clears or breaks up any land for cultivation or other purpose 30[ or cultivates or attempts to cultivate any land in any other manner] in the protected forest;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) in contravention of any rules made in this behalf by the Government, hunts, shoots, sets traps or snares or catches or kills any wild animals and birds, fishes or poisons water;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) establishes saw-pits or saw-benches or converts tree into timber without lawful authority in a protected forest;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) removes any timber from a protected forest;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to five years and shall not be less than six months and shall also be liable to fine which may extend to fifty thousand Taka and shall not be less than five thousand Taka, in addition such compensation for damages done to the forest as the convicting Court may direct to be paid.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Whenever fire is caused wilfully or by gross negligence in a protected forest, the Government may, not withstanding that any penalty has been inflicted under this section, direct that in such forest or any portion thereof the exercise of any right of pasture or to forest -produce shall be suspended for such period as it thinks fit.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Nothing in this Chapter to prohibit acts done in certain cases</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">34. Nothing in this Chapter shall be deemed to prohibit any act done with the permission in writing of the Forest-officer, or in accordance with rules made under section 32, or, except as regards any portion of a forest closed under section 30, or as regards any rights the exercise of which has been suspended under section 33, in the exercise of any right recorded under section 29.</p><p align="center">CHAPTER V</p><p align="center">OF THE CONTROL OVER FORESTS AND LANDS NOT BEING THE PROPERTY OF GOVERNMENT</p><p style="text-align: justify;">31[ Repealed]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">35. [Repealed by section 63 of the Private Forests Ordinance, 1959 (Ordinance No. XXXIV of 1959).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">32[ Repealed]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">36. [Repealed by section 63 of the Private Forests Ordinance, 1959 (Ordinance No. XXXIV of 1959).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">33[ Repealed]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">37. [Repealed by section 63 of the Private Forests Ordnance, 1959 (Ordinance No. XXXIV of 1959).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">34[ Repealed]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">38. [Repealed by section 63 of the Private Forests Ordinance, 1959 (Ordinance No. XXXIV of 1959).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Operation of the Privet Forest Ordinance</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">35[ 38A. (1) After commencement of this section, the Government may no longer exercise authority to vest control of forest land under sub-section (2) of section 6, section 7 or section 11 of the Private Forest Ordinance, 1959 (E. P. Ordi-nance No. XXXIV of 1959):</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Provided that the forest land already vested shall remain vested.</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) After commencement of this section, the Government may no longer exercise authority under section 3 of the Private Forests Ordinance, 1959 (E. P. Ordinance No. XXXIV of 1959) to require private forests to have working plans.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Notice of forest management activities</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">38B. (1) The Government may make rules for the purpose of issuing notice to owners or occupiers of neighbouring lands at least 30 days before understanding specified forest management activities that may pose a threat of harm to the environment or private or Government property or that the Government may wish to track for statistical purposes.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Within 20 days after receiving notice of a proposed activity under this section, upon finding that the proposed activity is likely to cause unreasonable damage to the environment or private or Government property, the Government may issue a written order to the owner or occupier of a land to alter or to refrain from the proposed activity to prevent or minimize such damage.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Restricted activities</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">38C. (1) The Government may make rules to prohibit, restrict or require a permit for land clearing use of pesticides, harvest on steep stopes, or other forest management activities on private land that may pose a threat to property, renewable natural resources or the productivity of land.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Government shall empower Forest-officers to issue such permits required under sub-section (1).</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Abetment of forest nuisances</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">38D. (1) Upon a finding that conditions on a land pose a risk of disease, insect outbreak fire or other harm to nearby renewable natural resources, the Government may issue a written order to the owner or occupier of the land to abate such a nuisance within 30 days, or sooner as may be specified in the notice, if the protection of renewable natural resources demands.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) To be effective, an order under sub-section (1) must be delivered personally to the owner or occupier of the land or sent to him by registered post with acknowledgement receipt due, or if the address of the person is unknown, affixed conspicuously at least two locations on the property.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) If the owner or the occupier fails to comply with an order under this section, the Government may enter the land, remove the nuisance and realize compensation as a public demand.]</p><p align="center">CHAPTER VI</p><p align="center">OF THE DUTY ON TIMBER AND OTHER FOREST-PRODUCE</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to impose duty on timber and other forest produce</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">39. (1) The Government may levy a duty in such manner, at such places and at such rates as it may declare by notification in the official Gazette on all timber or other forest-produce-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) which is produced in Bangladesh, and in respect of which the Government has any right;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) which is brought from any place outside Bangladesh or is transported from or to any place within Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) In every case in which such duty is directed to be levid ad valorem, the Government may fix by like notification the value on which such duty shall be assessed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Limit not apply to purchase money for royalty</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">40. Nothing in this Chapter shall be deemed to limit the amount, if any, chargeable as purchase-money or royalty on any timber or other forest-produce, although the same is levied on such timber or produce while in transit, in the same manner as duty is levied.</p><p align="center">CHAPTER VII</p><p align="center">OF THE CONTROL OF TIMBER AND OTHER FOREST-PRODUCE IN TRANSIT</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to make rules to regulate transit of forest-produce</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">41. (1) The control of all rivers and their banks as regards the floating of timber, as well as the control of all timber and other forest-produce in transit by land or water, is vested in the Government, and it may make rules to regulate the transit of all timber and other forest-produce.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) In particular and without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing power such rules may-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) prescribe the routes by which alone timber or other forest-produce may be imported, exported or moved into, from or within 36[ Bangladesh];</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) prohibit the import or export or moving of such timber or other produce without a pass from an officer duly authorized to issue the same, or otherwise than in accordance with the conditions of such pass;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) provide for the issue, production and return of such passes and for the payment of fees thereof;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) provide for the stoppage, reporting, examination and marking of timber or other forest-produce in transit, in respect of which there is reason to believe that any money is payable to the Government on account of the price thereof or on account of any duty, fee, royalty or charge due thereon, or, to which it is desirable for the purposes of this Act to affix a mark;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) provide for the establishment and regulation of depots to which such timber or other produce shall be taken by those in charge of it for examination, or for the payment of such money, or in order that such marks may be affixed to it; and the conditions under which such timber or other produce shall be brought to, stored at and removed from such depots;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) prohibit the closing up or obstructing of the channel or banks of any river used for the transit of timber or other forest-produce, and the throwing of grass, brushwood, branches or leaves into any such river or any act which may cause such river to be closed or obstructed;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g) provide for the prevention or removal of any obstruction of the channel or banks of any such river, and for recovering the cost of such prevention or removal from the person whose acts or negligence necessitated the same;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h) prohibit absolutely or subject to conditions, within specified local limits, the 37[ establishment of wood based industries including saw-mils, saw-pits, furniture marts and brick-fields], the converting, cutting, burning, concealing or making of timber, the altering or effacing of any marks on the same, or the possession or carrying of marking hammers or other implements used for marking timber;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) regulate the use of property marks for timber, and the registration of such marks; prescribe the time for which such registration shall hold good; limit the number of such marks that may be registered by any one person, and provide for the levy of fees for such registration.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Government may direct that any rule made under this section shall not apply to any specified class of timber or other forest-produce or to any specified local area.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">38[ Omitted ]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">41A. [Omitted by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Penalty for breach of rules made under section 41</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">42. (1) The Government may be such rules prescribe as penalties for the contravention thereof imprisonment for a term which may extend to 39[ three years and shall not be less than two months and shall also be laible to fine which may extend to ten thousand Taka and shall not be less than two thousand Taka].</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Such rules may provide there penalties which are double of those mentioned in sub-section (1) may be inflicted in cases where the offence is committed after sunset and before sunrise, or after preparation for resistance to lawful authority, or where the offender has been previously convicted of a like offence.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Government and Forest-officers not liable for damage to forest-produce at depot</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">43. The Government shall not be responsible for any loss or damage which may occur in respect of any timber or other forest-produce while at a depot established under a rule made under section 41, or while detained elsewhere, for the purposes of this Act; and no Forest-officer shall be responsible for any such loss or damage, unless he causes such loss or damage negligently, maliciously or fraudulently.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>All persons bound to aid in case of accident at depot</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">44. In case of any accident or emergency involving danger to any property at any such depot, every person employed at such depot, whether by the Government or by any private person, shall render any assistance to any Forest-officer or Police-officer demanding his aid in averting such danger or securing such property from damage or loss.</p><p align="center">CHAPTER VIII</p><p align="center">OF THE COLLECTION OF DRIFT AND STRANDED TIMBER</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Certain kinds of timber to be deemed property of Government until title thereto proved, and may be collected accordingly</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">45. (1) All timber found adrift, beached, stranded or sunk;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">all wood or timber bearing marks which have not been registered in accordance with the rules made under section 41, or on which the marks have been obliterated, altered or defaced by fire or otherwise; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">in such areas as the Government directs, all unmarked wood and timber;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shall be deemed to be the property of Government, unless and until any person establishes his right and title thereto, as provided in this Chapter.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Such timber may be collected by any Forest-officer or other person entitled to collect the same by virtue of any rule made under section 51, and may be brought to any depot which the Forest-officer may notify as a depot for the reception of drift timber.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette exempt any class of timber from the provisions of this section.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Notice to claimants of drift timber</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">46. Public notice shall from time to time be given by the Forest-office of timber collected under section 45. Such notice shall contain a description of the timber, and shall require any person claiming the same to present to such officer, within a period not less than two months from the date of such notice, a written statement of such claim.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Procedure on claim preferred to such timber</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">47. (1) When any such statement is presented as aforesaid, the Forest-officer may, after making such inquiry as he thinks fit, either reject the claim after recording his reasons for so doing, or deliver the timber to the claimant.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) If such timber is claimed by more than one person, the Forest-officer may either deliver the same to any of such persons whom he deems entitled thereto, or may refer the claimants to the Civil Courts, and retain the timber pending the receipt of an order from any such Court for its disposal.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Any person whose claim has been rejected under this section may, within three months from the date of such rejection, institute a suit to recover possession of the timber claimed by him; but no person shall recover any compensation or costs against the Government, or against any Forest-officer on account of such rejection, or the detention or removal of any timber, or the delivery thereof to any other person under this section.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) No such timber shall be subject to process of any Civil, Criminal or Revenue Court until it has been delivered, or a suit has been brought, as provided in this section.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Disposal of unclaimed timber</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">48. If no such statement is presented as aforesaid, or if the claimant omits to prefer his claim in the manner and within the period fixed by the notice issued under section 46, or on such claim, having been so preferred by him and having been rejected, omits to institute a suit to recover possession of such timber within the further period fixed by section 47,the ownership of such timber shall vest in the Government, or, when such timber has been delivered to another person under section 47, in such other person free from all encumbrances not created by him.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Government and its officers not liable for damage to such timber</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">49. The Government shall not be responsible for any loss or damage which may occur in respect of any timber collected under section 45, and no Forest-officer shall be responsible for any such loss or damage, unless he causes such loss or damage negligently, maliciously or fraudulently.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Payments to be made by claimant before timber is delivered to- him</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">50. No person shall be entitled to recover possession of any timber collected or delivered as aforesaid until he has paid to the Forest-officer or other person entitled to receive it such sum on account thereof as may be due under any rule made under section 51.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to make rule and prescribe penalties</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">51. (1) The Government may make rules to regulate the following matter, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) the salving, collection and disposal of all timber mentioned in section 45;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) the use and registration of boats used in salving and collecting timber;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) the amounts to be paid for salving, collecting, moving, storing or disposing of such timber; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) the use and registration of hammers and other instruments to be used for marking such timber.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Government may prescribe, as penalties for the contravention of any rules made under this section, imprisonment for a term which may extend to 40[ three years and shall not be less than two months and shall also be laible to fine which may extend to ten thousand Taka and shall not be less than two thousand Taka].</p><p align="center">CHAPTER IX</p><p align="center">PENALTIES AND PROCEDURE</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Seizure of property liable to confiscation</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">52. (1) When there is reason to believe that a forest-offence has been committed in respect of any forest-produce, such produce, together with all tools, 41[ vessels], vehicles or cattle used in committing any such offence, may be seized by any Forest-officer or Police-officer 42[ or any other officer authorized in this behalf by or under any other law inforce].</p><p style="text-align: justify;">43[ (1a) Every officer other than a Forest-officer seizing any property under this section shall hand over all the seized property mentioned under sub-section (1) along with the accused to the nearest forest-office for further legal proceedings:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that police-officers need not hand over the accused to the nearest forest-office but shall inform such forest-office of the arrest.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Every officer seizing any property under this section shall place on such property a mark indicating that the same has been so seized, and shall, as soon as may be, make a report of such seizure to the Magistrate having jurisdiction to try the offence on account of which the seizure has been made:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that, when the forest-produce with respect to which such offence is believed to have been committed is the property of Government, and the offender is unknown, it shall be sufficient if the officer makes, as soon as may be, a report of the circumstances to his official superior.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to release property seized under section 52</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">53. Any Forest-officer of a rank not inferior to that of a Ranger who, or whose subordinate, has seized any tools, 44[ vessels], vehicles or cattle under section 52, may release the same on the execution by the owner thereof of a bond for the production of the property so released, if and when so required, before the Magistrate having jurisdiction to try the offence on account of which the seizure has been made.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Procedure thereupon</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">54. Upon the receipt of any such report, the Magistrate shall, with all convenient dispatch, take such measures as may be necessary for the arrest and trial of the offender and the disposal of the property according to law.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Forest produce, tools, etc when liable to confiscation</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">55. (1) All timber or forest-produce which is not the property of Government and in respect of which a forest-offence has been committed, and all tools, boats, vehicles and used in committing any forest-offence, shall be liable to confiscation.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Such confiscation may be in addition to any other punishment prescribed for such offence.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Disposal on conclusion of trial for forest-offence of produce in respect which it was committed</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">56. When the trial of any forest-offence is concluded, any forest-produce in respect of which such offence has been committed shall, if it is the property of Government or has been confiscated, be taken charge of by a Forest-officer, and, in any other case, may be disposed of in such manner as the Court may direct.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Procedure when offender not known, or cannot be found</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">57. When the offender is not known or cannot be found the Magistrate may, if he finds that an offence has been committed, order the property in respect of which the offence has been committed to be confiscated and taken charge of by the Forest-officer, or to be made over to the person whom the Magistrate deems to entitled to the same:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that no such order shall be made until the expiration of one month from the date of seizing such property, or with out hearing the person, if any, claiming any right thereto, and the evidence, if any, which he may produce in support of his claim.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Procedure as to perishable property seized under section 52</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">58. The Magistrate may, notwithstanding anything herein before contained, direct the sale of any property seized under section 52 and subject to speedy and natural decay, and may deal with the proceeds as he would have dealt with such property if it had not been sold.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Appeal from orders under section 55, section 56, or section 57</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">59. The officer who made the seizure under section 52, or any of his official superiors, or any person claiming to be interested in the property so seized, may, within one month from the date of any order passed under section 55, section 56 or section 57, appeal therefrom to the Court to which orders made by such Magistrate are ordinarily appealable, and the order passed on such appeal shall be final.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Property when to vest in Government</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">60. When an order for the confiscation of any property has been passed under section 55 or section 57, as the case may be, and the period limited by section 59 for an appeal from such order has elapsed, and no such appeal has been preferred, or when, on such an appeal being preferred, the Appellate Court confirms such order in respect of the whole or a portion of such property, such property or such portion thereof, as the case may be, shall vest in the Government free from all incumbrances.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Saving of power to release property seized</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">61. Nothing herein before contained shall be deemed to prevent any officer empowered in this behalf by the Government from directing at any time the immediate release of any property seized under section 52.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Punishment for wrongful seizure</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">62. Any Forest-officer or Police-officer who vexatiously and unnecessarily seizes any property on pretence of seizing property liable to confiscation under this Act shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend</p><p style="text-align: justify;">to 45[ one year and shall not be less than one month and shall also be liable to fine which may extend to ten thousand Taka and shall not be less than two thousand Taka].</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Penalty for counterfeiting or defacing marks on trees and timber and for altering boundary marks</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">63. Whoever, with intent to cause damage or injury to the public or to any person, or to cause wrongful gain as defined in the 46[ Penal Code] -</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) knowingly counterfeits upon any timber or standing tree a mark used by Forest-officers to indicate that such timber or tree is the property of the Government or of some person, or that it may lawfully be                       </p></div></div>
116	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE HIGHWAYS ACT, 1925 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p align="center"><strong>THE HIGHWAYS ACT, 1925</strong></p><p align="center">(ACT NO. III OF 1925)</p><p align="right">[24th September, 1925]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 An Act to provide for the better maintenance and control of Government roads in Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to provide for the regulation and safety of traffic on Government roads in Bangladesh, for the prevention of obstruction and encroachments, and of nuisances on or near such roads, for the preservation of such roads, and for the temporary closing of such roads for repairs or other works, or for public purposes;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2[ * * *]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">It is hereby enacted as follows:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Short title, extent and commencement</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1.(1) This Act may be called the 3[ * * *] Highways Act, 1925.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It extends to the whole of Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) It shall come into force on such date as the Government may, by notification in the Official Gazette, direct.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Definition</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Act unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">"Government road" means a road vested in the Government, or under the control and administration of the Works Department of the Government, and includes?</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) the slope, berm, borrow-pits and side-drains of any such road;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) all lands and embankments vested in, or under the control and administration of, the said Works Department, and attached to a Government road;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) all bridges, culverts or causeways built on or across any Government road; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) all fences and posts on any Government road or on any land attached to a Government road, and all roadside trees on such land.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Temporary closing of Government road</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. The Government or any officer empower by the Government in this behalf may, by public note, displayed in a conspicuous portion of the road, declare any Government road or part thereof to be closed temporarily for the purpose of repairing such road, or for the purpose of constructing any sewer, drain, culvert or bridge, or for any other similar public purpose:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the Government or any officer empowered by the Government in this behalf shall, before declaring any such road or part thereof to be closed, be bound, were possible, to provide other reasonably sufficient means of access to holdings adjacent to such road or part, if no such means of access already exist:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided also that where there is a stretch of road over half a mile in length, the road or part thereof closed at any one time shall not exceed half a mile in length, and that, where possible, in such closed parts, an alternative route shall be provided.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Presumption by Government of control of roads placed under local authorities</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4[ 3A. The Government may, at any time, by notification, withdraw any Government road from the control and administration of any local authority under which it may have been placed by or under any law, and resume the control and administration thereof itself; and thereupon the right of control and administration of the local authority in respect of such road shall cease.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to make rules</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4.(1) The Government may, after previous publication, make rules-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) for the regulation and safety of traffic on Government roads;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5[ (ia)   for the regulation of construction works within ten meters of such Government roads called National Highways and Regional Highways;]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii) for the prevention of obstruction and encroachments and of nuisances on or near such roads;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(iii) for the preservation of such road; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(iv) for the temporary closing of such roads for repairs or other works, or for the purposes specifically set forth in section 3.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) and (3) [Omitted by section 6 of the Bengal Highways (Extension to Sylhet) Ordinance, 1959 (Ordinance No. LXII of 1959).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Penalties</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. In making any rule under this Act, the Government may direct that a breach thereof shall be punishable with a fine which may extend to 6[ ten thousand taka, and a continuing breach shall be punishable with a simple imprisonment for a period of six months and also with a further fine not exceeding one hundred taka] for every day after the date of the first conviction during which the offender is proved to have persisted in the offence.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">______________________________________________</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 Throughout this Act, except otherwise provided, the words “Bangladesh” and `Government` were substituted, for the words “East Pakistan” and “Provincial Government” respectively by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 The second paragraph of the preamble was omitted by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3 The word `Bengal` was omitted by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And the words and commas `ten taka, and when the breach is a continuing one, with a further fine not exceeding one taka` by section 2 of the Highways (Amendment) Act, 1994 (Act No. VI of 1994)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p>                       </div></div>
117	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE HINDU DISPOSITION OF PROPERTY ACT, 1916 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: center;"><strong>THE HINDU DISPOSITION OF PROPERTY ACT, 1916 </strong></p><p style="text-align: center;">(ACT NO. XV OF 1916)</p><p style="text-align: right;">[28th September, 1916]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">  An Act to remove certain existing disabilities in respect of the power of disposition of property by Hindus for the benefit of persons not in existence at the date of such disposition.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">  WHEREAS it is expedient to remove certain existing disabilities in respect of the power of disposition of property by Hindus for the benefit of persons not in existence at the date of such disposition; It is hereby enacted as follows:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Short title and extent</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1.(1) This Act may be called the Hindu Disposition of Property Act, 1916.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It extends to the whole of 1[ Bangladesh].</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Dispositions for the benefit of persons not in existence</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2.         Subject to the limitations and provisions specified in this Act, no disposition of property by a Hindu, whether by transfer inter vivos by will, shall be invalid by reason only that any person for whose benefit it may have been made was not in existence at the date of such disposition.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Limitations and conditions</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. The limitations and provisions referred to in section 2 shall be the following, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) in respect of dispositions by transfer inter vivos, those contained in Chapter II of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882, and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) in respect of dispositions by will, those contained in sections 113, 114, 115 and 116 of the Succession Act, 1925.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4[ Repealed]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. [Repealed by section 12 of the Transfer of Property (Amendment) Supplementary Act, 1929 (Act No. XXI of 1929).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Application of this Act to the khoja community</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. Where the 2[ Government] is of opinion that the Khoja community in 3[ Bangladesh] or any part thereof desire that the provisions of this Act should be extended to such community, it may, by notification in the official Gazette, declare that the provisions of this Act, with the substitution of the word "Khojas" or "Khoja", as the case may be, for the word "Hindus" or "Hindu" wherever those words occur, shall apply to that community in such area as may be specified in the notification, and this Act shall thereupon have effect accordingly.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">_________________________________________________________</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 The word `Bangladesh` was substituted, for the word `Pakistan` by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 The word `Government` was substituted, for the words `Provincial Government` by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3 The word `Bangladesh` was substituted, for the words `the Province` by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p> </div></div>
118	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE HINDU INHERITANCE (REMOVAL OF DISABILITIES) ACT, 1928 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: center;"><strong>THE HINDU INHERITANCE (REMOVAL OF DISABILITIES) ACT, 1928 </strong></p><p style="text-align: center;">(ACT NO. XII OF 1928)</p><p style="text-align: right;">[20th September, 1928]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">   An Act amend the Hindu Law relating to exclusion from inheritance of certain classes of heirs, and to remove to certain doubts.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">   WHEREAS it is expedient to amend the Hindu Law relating to exclusion from inheritance of certain classes of heirs, and to remove certain doubts; it is hereby enacted as follows:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Short title, extent and application</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">    1. (1) This Act may be called the Hindu Inheritance (Removal of Disabilities) Act, 1928.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">         (2) It extends to the whole of 1[ Bangladesh].</p><p style="text-align: justify;">          (3) It shall not apply to any person governed by the Dayabhaga School of Hindu Law.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong><strong>Persons not to be excluded from inheritance or rights in joint-family property</strong>,</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">  2. Notwithstanding any rule of Hindu Law or custom to the contrary, no person governed by the Hindu Law, other than a person who is and has been from birth a lunatic or idiot, shall be excluded from inheritance or from any right or share in joint-family property by reason only of any disease, deformity, or physical or mental defect.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Saving and exception</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">  3. Nothing contained in this Act shall affect any right which has accrued or any liability which has been incurred before the commencement thereof, or shall be deemed to confer upon any person any right in respect of any religious office or service or of the management of any religious or charitable trust which he would not have had if this Act had not been passed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">________________________________________</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 The word `Bangladesh` was substituted, for the word `Pakistan` by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p> </div></div>
119	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE HINDU LAW OF INHERITANCE (AMENDMENT) ACT, 1929 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p align="center"><strong>THE HINDU LAW OF INHERITANCE (AMENDMENT) ACT, 1929</strong></p><p align="center">(ACT NO. II OF 1929)</p><p align="right">[21st February, 1929]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Act to alter the order in which certain heirs of a Hindu male dying intestate are entitled to succeed to his estate.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to alter the order in which certain heirs of a Hindu male dying interstate are entitled to succeed to his estate; It is hereby enacted as follows:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Short title extent and application</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Act may be called the Hindu Law of Inheritance (Amendment) Act, 1929.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It extends to the whole of [Bangladesh], but it applies only to persons who, but for the passing of this Act, would have been subject to the law of Mitakshara in respect of the provision herein enacted, and it applies to such persons in respect only of the property of males not held in coparcenary and not disposed of by will.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Order of succession of certain heirs</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. A son's daughter, daughter's daughter, sister, and sister's son shall, in the order so specified, be entitled to rank in the order of succession next after a father's father and before a father's brother:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that a sister's son shall not include a son adopted after the sister's death.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Savings</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. Nothing in this Act shall-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) affect any special family or local custom having the force of law, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) vest in a son's daughter, daughter's daughter or sister an estate larger than, or different in kind from, that possessed by a female in property inherited by her from a male according to the school of Mitakshara law by which the male was governed, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) enable more than one person to succeed by inheritance to the estate of a deceased Hindu male which by a customary or other rule of succession descends to a single heir.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">________________________________________</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p>                       </div></div>
120	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">  THE IDENTIFICATION OF PRISONERS ACT, 1920 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p align="center"><strong>THE IDENTIFICATION OF PRISONERS ACT, 1920</strong></p><p align="center">(ACT NO. XXXIII OF 1920)</p><p align="right">[9th September, 1920]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Act to authorize the taking of measurements and photographs of convicts and others.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to authorize the taking of measurements and photographs of convicts and others; It is hereby enacted as follows:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Short title and extent</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1.(1) This Act may be called the Identification of Prisoners Act, 1920; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It extends to the whole of 1[ Bangladesh].</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Definitions</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2.  In this Act, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) "measurements" include finger impressions and foot-print impressions.;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) "police officer" means an officer in charge of a police-station, a police officer making an investigation under Chapter XIV of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, or any other police officer not below the rank of sub-inspector; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) "prescribed" means prescribed by rules made under this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Taking of measurements, etc, of convicted persons</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. Every person who has been-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) convicted of any offence punishable with rigorous imprisonment for a term of one year or upwards, or of any offence which would render him liable to enhanced punishment on a subsequent conviction, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) ordered to give security for his good behaviour under section 118 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shall, if so required, allow his measurements and photograph to be taken by a police officer in the prescribed manner.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Taking of measurements, etc, of non-convicted persons</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. Any person who has been arrested in connection with an offence punishable with rigorous imprisonment for a term of one year or upwards shall, if so required by a police officer, allow his measurements to be taken in the prescribed manner.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power of Magistrate to order a person to be measured or photographed</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5.         If a Magistrate is satisfied that, for the purposes of any investigation or proceeding under the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, it is expedient to direct any person to allow his measurements or photograph to be taken, he may make an order to that effect, and in that case the person to whom the order relates shall be produced or shall attend at the time and place specified in the order and shall allow his measurements or photograph to be taken, as the case may be, by a police officer:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that no order shall be made directing any person to be photographed except by a Magistrate of the first class:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided, further, that no order shall be made under this section unless the person has at some time been arrested in connection with such investigation of proceeding.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Resistance to the taking of measurements, etc</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6.(1) If any person who under this Act is required to allow his measurements or photograph to be taken resists or refuses to allow the taking of the same, it shall be lawful to use all means necessary to secure the taking thereof.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Resistance to or refusal to allow the taking of measurements or photographs under this Act shall be deemed to be an offence under section 186 of the 2[ Penal Code].</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Destruction of photographs and records of measurements, etc, on acquittal</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. Where any person who, not having been previously convicted of an offence punishable with rigorous imprisonment for a term of one year or upwards, has had his measurements taken or has been photographed in accordance with the provisions of this Act is released without trial or discharged or acquitted by any Court, all measurements and all photographs (both negatives and copies) so taken shall, unless the Court or (in a case where such person is released without trial) the District Magistrate or Sub-Divisional Officer for reasons to be recorded in writing otherwise directs, be destroyed or made over to him.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to make rules</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">8.(1) The 3[ Government] may make rules for the purpose of carrying into effect the provisions of this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) In particular and without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing provisions, such rules may provide for-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) restrictions on the taking of photographs of persons under section 5;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) the places at which measurements and photographs may be taken;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) the nature of the measurements that may be taken;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) the method in which any class or classes of measurements shall be taken;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) the dress to be worn by a person when being photographed under section 3; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) the preservation, safe custody, destruction and disposal of records of measurements and photographs.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Bar of suits</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. No suit or other proceeding shall lie against any person for anything done, or intended to be done, in good faith under this Act or under any rule made thereunder.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">--------------------------------------------------------------------</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 The word `Bangladesh` was substituted, for the word `Pakistan` by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 The words `Penal Code` were substituted, for the words `Pakistan Penal Code` by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3 The word `Government` was substituted, for the words `Provincial Government` by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p> </div></div>
121	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE JUVENILE SMOKING ACT, 1919 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p align="center"><strong>THE JUVENILE SMOKING ACT, 1919</strong></p><p align="center">(ACT NO. II OF 1919)</p><p align="right">[15th January, 1919]</p>An Act for the Prevention of Smoking by Juveniles.<p align="center"><strong>Preamble</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to make provision for the prevention of smoking by young persons;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">It is hereby enacted as follows:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Short title, local extent and commencement </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1.(1) This Act may be called the 1[ * * *] Juvenile Smoking Act, 1919.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It extends in the first instance to Dhaka:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the 2[ Government] may, from time to time, by notification in the Official Gazette, extend this Act to any other town or place in 3[ Bangladesh].</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) It shall come into force on such date as the 4[ Government] may, by notification in the Official Gazette, direct.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Definitions </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2.   In this Act, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) "cigarettes" include cut tobacco rolled up in paper, tobacco leaf, or other material in such form as to be capable of immediate use for smoking;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) "police-officer" means a member of an established police force above the rank of a head constable; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) "tobacco" means tobacco in any form, and includes any smoking mixture intended as a substitute for tobacco.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Prohibition against sale of tobacco, etc, to young persons</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3.(1) No person shall sell or give to a person apparently under the age of sixteen years any tobacco, pipes or cigarette papers, whether for his own use or not:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that a person shall not be guilty of an offence under this sub-section for selling tobacco, other than cigarettes, to a person apparently under the age of sixteen years if he did not know, and had no reason to believe that it was for the use of that person.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) If any person contravenes the provisions of sub-section (1), he shall be liable on summary conviction before a Magistrate to a fine not exceeding ten Taka and in the case of a second offence to a fine not exceeding twenty rupees, and in the case of a subsequent offence to a fine not exceeding fifty rupees.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power of police-officers and others to seize and destroy tobacco, etc, in the possession of a young person in certain places</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. It shall be lawful for a police-officer in uniform, or any other person or class of persons duly authorized by the 5[ Government] in this behalf, to seize any tobacco, pipes or cigarette papers in the possession of any person apparently under the age of sixteen years whom he finds smoking in any street or public place, and to destroy any such article.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Institution of proceedings</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. No Magistrate shall take cognizance of an offence under this Act, except upon a complaint made by, or at the instance of, the parent or guardian of the young person concerned or a police-officer or other person empowered to make a seizure under section 4.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Act not to apply in certain cases</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. The provisions of this Act shall not apply when the person to whom the tobacco, pipes or cigarette papers are sold, or in whose possession they are found, was at the time employed by a manufacturer of, or dealer in, such articles either wholesale or retail, for the purposes of his business.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">----------------------------------------------------------------------</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 The word `Bengal` was omitted by Article 6 of the Bangladesh (Adaptation of Existing Laws) Order, 1972 (President`s Order No. 48 of 1972)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 The word `Government` was replaced, for the words `Provincial Government` by Article 8 of the Bangladesh (Adaptation of Existing Laws) Order, 1972 (President`s Order No. 48 of 1972)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3 The word `Bangladesh` was replaced, for the words `East Pakistan` by Article 5 of the Bangladesh (Adaptation of Existing Laws) Order, 1972 (President`s Order No. 48 of 1972)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4 The word `Government` was replaced, for the words `Provincial Government` by Article 8 of the Bangladesh (Adaptation of Existing Laws) Order, 1972 (President`s Order No. 48 of 1972)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5 The word `Government` was replaced, for the words `Provincial Government` by Article 8 of the Bangladesh (Adaptation of Existing Laws) Order, 1972 (President`s Order No. 48 of 1972)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p> </div></div>
122	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE LEGAL PRACTITIONERS (FEES) ACT, 1926 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p align="center"><strong>THE LEGAL PRACTITIONERS (FEES) ACT, 1926</strong></p><p align="center">(ACT NO.
