(1) Subject to, and in accordance with, the provisions of this Act and the rules made thereunder, the Official Trustee may, if he thinks fit,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) act as an ordinary trustee;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) be appointed trustee by a Court of competent jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Save as hereinafter expressly provided, the Official Trustee shall have the same powers, duties and liabilities, and be entitled to the same rights and privileges and be subject to the same control and orders of the Court as any other trustee acting in the same capacity.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Official Trustee may decline, either absolutely or except on such conditions as he may impose, to except any trust.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The Official Trustee shall not accept any trust under any composition or scheme of arrangement for the benefit of creditors, nor of any estate known or believed by him to be insolvent.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) The Official Trustee shall not, save as provided by any rules made under this Act, accept any trust for a religious purpose or any trust which involves the management or carrying on of any business.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(6) The Official Trustee shall not administer the estate of a deceased person, unless he is expressly appointed sole executor of, and sole trustee under, the will of such person.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(7) The Official Trustee shall always be sole trustee, and it shall not be lawful to appoint the Official Trustee to be trustee along with any other person.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Official Trustee may with consent be appointed trustee of settlement by grantor</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. (1) Any person intending to create a trust other than a trust which the Official Trustee is prohibited from accepting under the provisions of this Act may by the instrument creating the trust and with the consent of the Official Trustee, appoint him by that name or any other sufficient description to be the trustee of the property subject to such trust:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the consent of the Official Trustee shall be recited in the said instrument and that such instrument shall be duly executed by the Official Trustee.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Upon such appointment the property subject to the trust shall vest in such Official Trustee, and shall be held by him upon the trusts declared in such instrument.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Appointment of Official Trustee as trustee by will</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. When the Official Trustee has by that name or any other sufficient description been appointed trustee under any will, the executor of the will of the testator or the administrator of his estate shall, after obtaining probate or letters of administration, notify in the prescribed manner the contents of such will to such Official Trustee; and, if such Official Trustee, consents to accept the trust, then upon the execution by such executor or administrator of an instrument in writing transferring the property subject to the trust to the Official Trustee such property shall vest in such Official Trustee, and shall be held by him upon the trusts expressed in the said will:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the consent of the Official Trustee shall be recited in the said instrument and that such instrument shall be duly executed by the Official Trustee.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power of High Court Division to appoint Official Trustee to be trustee of property</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. (1) If any property is subject to a trust other than a trust which the Official Trustee is prohibited from accepting under the provisions of this Act, and there is no trustee within the local limits of the ordinary or extraordinary original civil jurisdiction of the High Court Division willing or capable to act in the trust, the High Court Division may on application make an order for the appointment of the Official Trustee by that name with his consent to be the trustee of such property.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Upon such order such property shall vest in the Official Trustee and shall be held by him upon the same trusts as the same was held previously to such order, and the previous trustee or trustees (if any) shall be exempt from liability as trustees of such property save in respect of acts done before the date of such order.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Nothing in this section shall be deemed to affect the provisions of the Trustees' and Mortgagees' Powers Act, 1866, or the Trusts Act, 1882.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power of private trustees to appoint Official Trustee to be trustee of property</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">11. (1) If any property is subject to a trust other than a trust which the Official Trustee is prohibited from accepting under the provisions of this Act, and all the trustees of the surviving or continuing trustee or trustees and all persons beneficially interested in the trusts are desirous that the Official Trustee shall be appointed in the room of such trustee or trustees, it shall be lawful for such trustee or trustees, by an instrument in writing to appoint the Official Trustee by that name or any other sufficient description with his consent to be the trustee of such property:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the consent of the Official Trustee shall be recited in the said instrument and that such instrument shall be duly executed by him.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Upon such appointment such property shall vest in the Official Trustee and shall be held by him upon the same trusts as the same was held previously to such appointment, and the previous trustee or trustees shall be exempt from all liability as trustees of such property save in respect of acts done before the date of such appointment.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Executor or administrator may pay to Official Trustee legacy, share, etc, of infant or lunatic</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">12. (1) If any infant or lunatic is entitled to any gift, legacy or share of the assets of a deceased person, it shall be lawful for the person by whom such gift is made, or executor or administrator by whom such legacy or share is payable or transferable or any trustee of such gift, legacy or share, to transfer the same by an instrument in writing to the Official Trustee by that name or any other sufficient description with his consent:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the consent of the Official Trustee shall be recited in the said instrument and that such instrument shall be duly executed by the Official Trustee.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Any money or property transferred to the Official Trustee under this section shall vest in him and shall be subject to the same provisions as are contained in this Act as to other property vested in such Official Trustee.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Official Trustee not to be required to give bond or security</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">13. (1) No Official Trustee shall be required by any Court to enter into any bond or security on his appointment in any capacity under this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) No Official Trustee or Deputy Official Trustee shall be required to verify otherwise than by his signature any petition presented by him under the provisions of this Act, and if the facts stated in any such petition are not within the Official Trustee's personal knowledge, the petition may be verified and subscribed by any person competent to make the verification.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Entry of Official Trustee not to constitute notice of a trust</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">14. The entry of the Official Trustee by that name in the books of a company shall not constitute notice of a trust; and a company shall not be entitled to object to enter the name of the Official Trustee on its register by reason only that the Official Trustee is a corporation; and, in dealing with property, the fact that the person dealt with is the Official Trustee shall not of itself constitute notice of a trust.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to examine on Oath</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9[ 14A. The Official Trustee 10[ * * *] may, whenever he desires, for the purposes of this Act, to satisfy himself regarding any question of fact, examine upon oath (which he is hereby authorized to administer) any person who is willing to be examined by him regarding such question.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Liability of Government</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">15. (1) The revenues of the Government shall be liable to make good all sums required to discharge any liability which the Official Trustee, if he were a private trustee, would be personally liable to discharge, except when the liability is one to which neither the Official Trustee nor any of his officers has in any way contributed or which neither he nor any of his officers could by the exercise of reasonable diligence have averted, and in either of those cases the Official Trustee shall not, nor shall the revenues of the Government be subject to any liability.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Nothing in sub-section (1) shall be deemed to render the revenues of the Government or any Official Trustee appointed under this Act liable for anything done by or under the authority of any Official Trustee before the commencement of this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Notice of suit not required in certain cases</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">16. Nothing in section 80 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, shall apply to any suit against the Official Trustee in which no relief is claimed against him personally.</p><p align="center">PART IV</p><p align="center">FEES</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Fees</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">17. (1) There shall be charged in respect of the duties of the Official Trustee such fees, whether by way of percentage or otherwise, as the Government may prescribe.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The fees under this section may be at different rates for different properties or classes of properties or for different duties, and shall, so far as may be, be arranged so as to produce an amount sufficient to discharge the salaries and all other expenses incidental to the working of this Act (including such sum as Government may determine to be required to insure the revenues of the Government against loss under this Act).</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Disposal of fees</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">18. (1) All expenses which might be retained or paid out of the trust fund, if the Official Trustee were a private trustee, shall be so retained or paid, and any fees leviable under this Act shall be retained or paid in like manner as and in addition to such expenses.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Official Trustee shall transfer and pay to such authority and in such manner and at such times as the Government may prescribe, all fees received by him under this Act, and the same shall be carried to the account and credit of the Government.</p><p align="center">PART V</p><p align="center">AUDIT</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Auditors to be appointed to examine Official Trustee’s accounts, etc, and to report to Government</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">19. (1) The accounts of the Official Trustee shall be audited at least once annually and at any other time if the Government so direct by the prescribed person and in the prescribed manner.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The auditor shall examine such accounts, and shall forward to Government a statement thereof in the prescribed form, together with a report thereon and a certificate signed by him showing-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) whether the accounts have been audited in the prescribed manner, and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(aa) whether, so far as can be ascertained by such audit, the accounts contain a full and true account of everything which ought to be contained therein, and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) whether the books, which by any rules made under this Act are directed to be kept by the Official Trustee, have been duly and regularly kept, and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) whether the trust funds and securities have been duly kept and invested and deposited in the manner prescribed by this Act or any rules made thereunder;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">or (as the case may be) that such accounts are deficient, or that the Official Trustee has failed to comply with this Act or the rules made thereunder, in such respects as may be specified in such certificate.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Auditor’s power to summon witnesses and to call for documents</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">20. (1) Every auditor shall have the powers of a Civil Court under the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) to summon any person whose presence he may think necessary to attend him from time to time, and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) to examine any person, on oath to be by him administered, and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) to issue a commission for the examination on interrogatories or otherwise of any person, and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) to summon any person to produce any document or thing, the production of which appears to be necessary for the purposes of such audit or examination.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Any person who, when summoned, refuses, or without reasonable cause neglects to attend or to produce any document or thing or attends and refuses to be sworn, or to be examined shall be deemed to have committed an offence within the meaning of, and punishable under, section 188 of the 11[ Penal Code], and the auditor shall report every case of such refusal or neglect to Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Costs of audit, etc, how paid</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">21. The cost of and incidental to every such audit and examination shall be determined in accordance with rules made by the Government and shall be defrayed in the prescribed manner.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Right of beneficiary to inspection and copies of accounts</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">22. Every beneficiary under a trust which is being administered by the Official Trustee shall, subject to such conditions and restrictions as may be prescribed, be entitled, at all reasonable times, to inspect the accounts of such trust, and the report and certificate of the auditor and, on payment of the prescribed fees, to be furnished with copies thereof or extracts therefrom, and nothing in the Trusts Act, 1882, shall affect the provisions of this section.</p><p align="center">PART VI</p><p align="center">MISCELLANEOUS</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Transfer to Government of accumulations in the hands of Official Trustee</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">23. When any moneys payable to a beneficiary under a trust have been in the hands of any Official Trustee for a period of twelve years or upwards whether before or after the commencement of this Act in consequence of the Official Trustee having been unable to trace the person entitled to receive the same, such moneys shall be transferred in the prescribed manner to the account and credit of the Government:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that no such moneys shall be so transferred if any suit or proceeding is pending in respect thereof in any Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Mode of proceeding by claimant to recover money so transferred</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">24. (1) If any claim is made to any moneys so transferred and such claim is established to the satisfaction of the prescribed authority, the Government shall pay to the claimant the amount in respect of which the claim is established.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) If such claim is not established to the satisfaction of the prescribed authority, the claimant may, without prejudice to his right to take any other proceedings for the recovery of such moneys, apply by petition to the High Court Division against the Government and, after taking such evidence as it thinks fit, such Court shall make such order on the petition in regard to the payment of such moneys as it thinks fit, and such order shall be binding on all parties to the proceedings.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Court may further direct by whom all or any part of the costs of such proceedings shall be paid.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power of High Court Division to make orders in respect of property vested in Official Trustee</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">25. The High Court Division may make such orders as it thinks fit respecting any trust property vested in the Official Trustee, or the interest or produce thereof.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Who may apply for order under Act</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">26. Any order under this Act may be made, on the application of any person beneficially interested in any trust property or of any trustee thereof.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Order of Court to have effect of a decree</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">27. Any order made by High Court Division under this Act shall have the same effect as a decree.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>General powers of administration</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">28. The Official Trustee may, in addition to and not in derogation of any other powers of expenditure lawfully exercisable by him, incur expenditure-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) on such acts as may be necessary for the proper care and management of any property belonging to any trust administered by him; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) with the sanction of the High Court Division on such religious, charitable and other objects and on such improvements as may be reasonable and proper in the case of such property.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Transfer of trust property by Official Trustee to original trustee or any other trustee</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">29. (1) Nothing in this Act shall be deemed to prevent the transfer by the Official Trustee of any property vested in him to-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) the original trustee (if any); or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) any other lawfully appointed trustee; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) any other person if the Court so directs.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Upon such transfer such property shall vest in such trustee, and shall be held by him upon the same trusts as those upon which it was held prior to such transfer, and the Official Trustee shall be exempt from all liability as trustee of such property except in respect of acts done before such transfer:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that, in the case of any transfer under this section, the Official Trustee shall be entitled to retain out of the property any fees leviable in accordance with the provisions of this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Rules</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">30. (1) The Government shall make rules for carrying into effect the objects of this Act and for regulating the proceedings of the Official Trustee in the discharge of his duties.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) In particular and without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing power, such rules may provide for-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) the accounts to be kept by the Official Trustee and the audit and inspection thereof;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) the safe custody, and deposit of the funds and securities which come into the hands of the Official Trustee;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) the remittance of sums of money in the hands of the Official Trustee in cases in which such remittances are required;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) the statements, schedules and other documents to be submitted by the Official Trustee to Government or to any other authority and the publication of such statements, schedules or other documents;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) the realization of the cost of preparing any such statements, schedules or other documents;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) subject to the provisions of this Act, the fees to be paid thereunder and the collection and accounting for any fees so fixed;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g) the manner in which and the person by whom the costs of and incidental to any audit under the provisions of this Act are to be determined and defrayed;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h) the manner in which summonses issued under the provisions of section 20 are to be served and the payment of the expenses of any persons summoned are examined under the provisions of this Act and of any expenditure incidental to such examination;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) the acceptance by the Official Trustee of trusts for religious purposes and trusts which involve the management or carrying on of business; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(j) any matter in this Act directed to be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Rules made under the provisions of this section shall be published in the official Gazette, and shall thereupon have effect as if enacted in this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>False evidence</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">12[ 30A. Whoever, during any examination authorized by this Act, makes upon oath a statement which is false and which he either knows or believes to be false or does not believe to be true, shall be deemed to have intentionally given false evidence in a stage of a judicial proceeding.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[Repealed]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">31. [Repealed by the Government of India (Adaptation of Indian Laws) Order, 1937.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Savings of provisions of Registration Act, 1908</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">32. Nothing contained in this Act shall be deemed to affect the provisions of the Registration Act, 1908.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[Omitted]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">32A. [Omitted by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[Repealed]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">33. [Repealed by section 2 and Schedule of the Repealing Act, 1927 (Act No. XII of 1927).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">--------------------------------------------------------------------------------</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 Throughout this Act, except otherwise provided, the words `High Court Division` were substituted, for the words `High Court` or `a High Court` by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 The word `Bangladesh` was substituted, for the word `Pakistan` by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3 The word `Government` was substituted, for the words `Central Government` by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4 Clauses (1) and (2) were omitted by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5 Clause (8) was omitted by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973).</p><p 134	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">   THE PASSPORT ACT, 1920 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p align="center"><strong>THE PASSPORT ACT, 1920</strong></p><p align="center">(ACT NO. XXXIV OF 1920)</p><p align="right">[9th September, 1920]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 An Act to take power to require passports of persons entering Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to take power to require passports of persons entering Bangladesh;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">It is hereby enacted as follows:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Short title and extent</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1.(1) This Act may be called the Passport Act, 1920.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It extends to the whole of Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Definitions</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Act, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">"entry" means entry by water, land or air;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">"passport" means a passport for the time being in force issued or renewed by the prescribed authority and satisfying the conditions prescribed relating to the class of passports to which it belongs; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">"prescribed" means prescribed by rules made under this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to make rules</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3.(1) The Government may make rules requiring that persons entering Bangladesh shall be in possession of passports, and for all matters ancillary or incidental to that purpose.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing power such rules may-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) prohibit the entry into Bangladesh or any part thereof of any person who has not in his possession a passport issued to him;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) prescribe the authorities by whom passports must have been issued or renewed , and the conditions with which they must comply, for the purposes of this Act; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) provide for the exemption, either absolutely or on any condition, of any person or class of persons from any provision of such rules.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Rules made under this section may provide that any contravention thereof or of any order issued under the authority of any such rule shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) All rules made under this section shall be published in the official Gazette, and shall thereupon have effect as if enacted in this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power of arrest</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4.(1) Any officer of police, not below the rank of a sub-inspector, and any officer of the Customs Department empowered by a general or special order of the Government in this behalf may arrest without warrant any person who has contravened or against whom a reasonable suspicion exists that he has contravened any rule or order made under section 3.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Every officer making an arrest under this section shall, without unnecessary delay, take or send the person arrested before a Magistrate having jurisdiction in the case or to the officer in charge of the nearest police-station and the provisions of section 61 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, shall, so far as may be, apply in the case of any such arrest.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power of removal</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. The Government may, by general or special order, direct the removal of any person from Bangladesh who, in contravention of any rule made under section 3 prohibiting entry into Bangladesh without passport, has entered therein, and thereupon any officer of the Government shall have all reasonable powers necessary to enforce such direction.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6[ Omitted]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6.  [Omitted by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">--------------------------------------------------------------------------</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 Throughout this Act, except otherwise provided, the words `Bangladesh` and `Government` were substituted, for the words `Pakistan` and `Central Government` respectively by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p> </div></div>
135	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE POISONS ACT, 1919 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p align="center"><strong>THE POISONS ACT, 1919</strong></p><p align="center">(ACT NO. XII OF 1919)</p><p align="right">[3rd September, 1919]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 An Act to consolidate and amend the law regulating the importation, possession and sale of poisons.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to consolidate and amend the law regulating the importation, possession and sale of poisons;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">It is hereby enacted as follows:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Short title and extent </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1.(1) This Act may be called, the Poisons Act, 1919.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It extends to the whole of Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Power of the Government to regulate possession for sale and sale of any poison </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2.(1) The Government may by rule regulate within the whole or any part of 2[ Bangladesh] the possession for sale and the sale, whether wholesale or retail, of any specified poison.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) In particular, and without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing power, such rules may provide for-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) the grant of licences to possess any specified poison for sale, wholesale or retail, and the fixing of the fee (if any) to be charged for such licences;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) the classes of persons to whom alone such licences may be granted;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) the classes of persons to whom alone any such poison may be sold;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) the maximum quantity of any such poison which may be sold to any one person;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) the maintenance by vendors of any such poison of registers of sales, the particulars to be entered in such registers, and the inspection of the same;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) the safe custody of such poisons and the labelling of the vessels, packages or coverings in which any such poison is sold or possessed for sale; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g) the inspection and examination of any such poison when possessed for sale by any such vendor.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to prohibit importation into Bangladesh of any poison except under license</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, prohibit, except under and in accordance with the conditions of a licence, the importation into Bangladesh across any customs frontier defined by the Government of any specified poison, and may by rule regulate the grant of licences.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to regulate possession of any poison in certain areas</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4.(1)     The Government may by rule regulate the possession of any specified poison in any local area in which the use of such poison for the purpose of committing murder or mischief by poisoning cattle appears to it to be of such frequent occurrence as to render restrictions on the possession thereof desirable.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) In making any rule under sub-section (1), the Government may direct that any breach thereof shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine which may extend to one thousand Taka, or with both, together with confiscation of the poison in respect of which the breach has been committed, and of the vessels, packages or coverings in which the same is found.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Presumption as to specified poisons</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5.         Any substance specified as a poison in a rule made or notification issued under this Act shall be deemed to be a poison for the purpose of this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Penalty for unlawful importation, etc</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6.(1) Whoever-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        commits a breach of any rule made under section 2, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) imports without a licence into Bangladesh across a customs frontier defined by the Government any poison the importation of which is for the time being restricted under section 3, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) breaks any condition of a licence for the importation of any poison granted to him under section 3,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shall be punishable,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) on a first conviction, with imprisonment for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine which may extend to five hundred Taka, or with both, and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii) on a second or subsequent conviction, with imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to one thousand Taka, or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Any poison in respect of which an offence has been committed under this section, together with the vessels, packages or coverings in which the same is found, shall be liable to confiscation.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to issue search warrants</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7.(1) The District Magistrate, 3[ the Sub-divisional Magistrate and, in 4[ a Metropolitan Area], the Police Commissioner], may issue a warrant for the search of any place in which he has reason to believe or to suspect that any poison is possessed or sold in contravention of this Act or any rule thereunder, or that any poison liable to confiscation under this Act is kept or concealed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The person to whom the warrant is directed may enter and search the place in accordance therewith, and the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, relating to search warrants shall, as far as may be, be deemed to apply to the execution of the warrant.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Rules</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">8.(1) In addition to any other power to make rules hereinbefore conferred the Government may make rules generally to carry out the purposes and objects of this Act 5[ ***].</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Every power to make rules conferred by this Act shall be subject to the condition of the rules being made after previous publication.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) All rules made by the 6[ * * *] Government under this Act shall be published in the official Gazette and on such publication shall have effect as if enacted in this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Savings</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9.(1) Nothing in this Act or in any licence granted or rule made thereunder shall extend to, or interfere with, anything done in good faith in the exercise of his profession as such by a medical or veterinary practitioner.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Notwithstanding anything hereinbefore contained, the Government may by general or special order declare that all or any of the provisions of this Act 7[ * * *] shall be deemed not to apply to any article or class of articles of commerce specified in such order, or to any poison or class of poisons used for any purpose so specified.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) 8[ The Government] may, by general or special order, either wholly or partially-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) exempt from the operation of any such rules, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) exclude from the scope of the exemption provided by sub-section (1),</p><p style="text-align: justify;">any person or class of persons either generally or in respect of any poisons specified in the order.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[Repealed]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">10.       [Repealed by the Repealing Act, 1927 (Act No. XII of 1927).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">----------------------------------------------------------------------------------</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 Throughout this Act, except otherwise provided, the words `Bangladesh`, `Government` and `Taka` were substituted, for the words `Pakistan`, `Provincial Government` or `Central Government` or `Central Government or by the Provincial Government` and `rupees` respectively by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 The word `Bangladesh` was substituted, for the words `the territories under its administration` by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3 The words and commas `the Sub-divisional Magistrate and, in the Dacca Metropolitan Area, the Police Commissioner` were substituted, for the words `and the Sub-divisional Magistrate` by the Schedule of the Dhaka Metropolitan Police (Amendment) Ordinance, 1976 (Ordinance No. LXIX of 1976)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4 The words `a Metropolitan Area` were substituted, for the words `the Dacca Metropolitan Area` by the Schedule III of the Chittagong Metropolitan Police Ordinance, 1978 (Ordinance No. XLVIII of 1978)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5 The words and figure `except section 3` were omitted by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6 The words `Central Government or by the Provincial` were omitted by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p 136	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE POLICE (INCITEMENT TO DISAFFECTION) ACT, 1922</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p align="center"><strong>THE POLICE (INCITEMENT TO DISAFFECTION) ACT, 1922</strong></p><p align="center">(ACT NO. XXII OF 1922)</p><p align="right">[5th October, 1922]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 An Act to provide a penalty for spreading of disaffection among the police and for kindred offences.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to penalize the spreading of disaffection among the police and other kindred offences; It is hereby enacted as follows:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Short title, extent and commencement</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1.(1) This Act may be called the Police (Incitement to Disaffection) Act, 1922.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It extends to the whole of Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) It shall come into force in 2[ Bangladesh or part thereof] on such date as the 3[ Government] may, by notification in the official Gazette, direct.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Definition</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Act, the expression "member of a police-force" means any person appointed or enrolled for the performance of police duties under any enactment specified in the Schedule.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Penalty for causing disaffection, etc</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. Whoever intentionally causes or attempts to cause, or does any act which he knows is likely to cause, disaffection towards Bangladesh or the Government established by law in Bangladesh amongst the members of a police-force, or induces or attempts to induce, or does any act which he knows is likely to induce, any member of a police-force to withhold his services or to commit a breach of discipline shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to two hundred 4[ Taka], or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Explanation- Expressions of disapprobation of the measures of the Government with a view to obtain their alteration by lawful means, or of disapprobation of the administrative or other action of the Government, do not constitute an offence under this section unless they cause or are made for the purpose of causing or are likely to cause disaffection.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Saving of acts done by police associations and other persons for certain purposes</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4.         Nothing shall be deemed to be an offence under this Act which is done in good faith-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) for the purpose of promoting the welfare or interests of any member of a police-force by inducing him to withhold his services in any manner authorized by law; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) by or on behalf of any association formed for the purpose of furthering the interests of members of a police-force as such, where the association has been authorized or recognized by the Government and the act done is done under any rules or articles of the association which have been approved by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Sanction to trial of offences by subordinate Courts</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. No Court shall proceed to the trial of any offence under this Act except with the previous sanction, or on the complaint, of the District Magistrate.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Trial of cases</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6.(1) No Court inferior to that of a Magistrate of the first class shall try any offence under this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Notwithstanding anything contained in Chapter XXII of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, no offence under this Act shall be triable summarily.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">------------------------------------------------------------------</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 Throughout this Act, except otherwise provided, the word `Bangladesh` was substituted, for the word `Pakistan` by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 The words `Bangladesh or part thereof` were substituted, for the words `any Province or part of a Province` by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3 The word `Government` was substituted, for the words `Provincial Government` by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4 The word `Taka` was substituted, for the word `rupees` by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p>                       </div></div>
137	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE POST OFFICE CASH CERTIFICATES ACT, 1917 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p align="center"><strong>THE POST OFFICE CASH CERTIFICATES ACT, 1917</strong></p><p align="center">(ACT NO. XVIII OF 1917)</p><p align="right">[19th September, 1917]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 An Act to restrict the transfer of Post Office 5-year Cash Certificates and to provide for the payment of Certificates standing in the name of deceased persons.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to restrict the transfer of Post Office 5-year Cash Certificates and to provide for the payment of Certificates standing in the name of deceased persons; It is hereby enacted as follows:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Short title </strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1.         This Act may be called the Post Office Cash Certificates Act, 1917.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Prohibition of transfer of post Office 5-year Cash Certificates without the consent of an authorized officer</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2.(1) Notwithstanding any provision in any enactment or any rule of law for the time being in force to the contrary, no transfer (whether made before or after the commencement of this Act) of a Post Office 5-year Cash Certificate shall be valid without the previous consent in writing of an officer of the Post Office authorized by general or special order of the Government in that behalf.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) In this section "transfer" means a transfer inter vivos and does not include a transfer by operation of law.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Payment on death of holder of Post Office 5-year Cash Certificate</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3.(1) If a person dies and is at the time of his death the holder of a Post Office 5-year Cash Certificate, payment of the sum for the time being due on such Certificate may be made in the manner provided in the Government Savings Banks Act, 1873, for the payment of deposits belonging to the estates of deceased persons, and the provisions of sections 4 to 9 of the said Act shall apply accordingly as if the holder of such Certificate were a depositor in a Government Savings Bank and the sum for the time being due on such certificate were a deposit in such a Bank and as if for the words "three thousand" in section 8 of the said Act the words "five thousand" were substituted:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the powers conferred by the said provisions on the Secretary of a Government Savings Bank shall be exercisable by the Postmaster-General for the area within which the post office of issue of such Certificate is situate or if that area is in 2[ India or Pakistan], by the Postmaster-General for such area in Bangladesh as the Government may by General or special order specify in this behalf:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided further that, where in anyone case payment is to be made of Certificates issued from more post offices than one, the said powers shall be exercisable by the Postmaster-General for the area in which any of the said post offices is situate.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Nothing in sub-section (1) shall be deemed to require any person to accept payment of the amount due on a Post Office 5-year Cash Certificate before the same has reached maturity.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">------------------------------------------------------------------------------</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 Throughout this Act, except otherwise provided, the words `Bangladesh` and `Government` were substituted, for the words `Pakistan` and `Central Government` respectively by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 The words `India or Pakistan` were substituted, for the word `India` by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p> </div></div>
138	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE PROVIDENT FUNDS ACT, 1925 </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p align="center" style="text-align: center;"><strong>THE PROVIDENT FUNDS ACT, 1925</strong></p><p align="center" style="text-align: center;">(ACT NO. XIX OF 1925)</p><p align="right" style="text-align: right;">[27th August, 1925]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 An Act to amend and consolidate the law relating to Government and other Provident Funds.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to amend and consolidate the law relating to Government and other Provident Funds; It is hereby enacted as follows:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Short title extent and commencement</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1.(1) This Act may be called the Provident Funds Act, 1925.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It extends to the whole of Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) It shall come into force on such date as the Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, appoint.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Definitions</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Act, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) "compulsory deposit" means a subscription to, or deposit in, Provident Fund which, under the rules of the Fund, is not, until the happening of some specified contingency, repayable on demand otherwise than for the purpose of the payment of permit in respect of policy of life insurance or the payment of subscriptions or premia in respect of a family pension fund, and includes any contribution and any interest or increment which has accrued under the rules of the Fund on any such subscription, deposit, or contribution, and also any such subscription deposit, contribution interest or increment remaining to the credit of the subscriber or depositor after the happening any such contingency;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) "contribution" means any amount credited in a Provident Found, by any authority administering the Fund, by way of addition to, a subscription to, or deposit or balance at the credit of an individual account in, the Fund; and "contributory Provident Fund" means a Provident Fund the rules or which provide for the crediting of contributions;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) "dependant" means any of the following relatives of a deceased subscriber to, or a depositor in, a Provident Fund, namely, a wife, husband, parent, child, minor brother, unmarried sister and a deceased son's widow and child, and, where no parent of the subscriber or depositor is alive, a paternal grand-parent;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) "Government Provident Fund" means a Provident Fund, other than a Railway provident Fund, constituted by the authority of 2[ the Government] for any class or classes of persons in the service of the 3[ Republic] or of persons employed in educational institutions or employed by bodies existing solely for educational purposes, 4[ * * *];</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) "Provident Fund" means a fund in which subscriptions or deposits of any class or classes of employees are received and held on their individual accounts, and includes any contribution and any interest or increment accruing on such subscriptions, deposits or contributions under the rules of the Fund;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) "Railway administration" means-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5[ * * *]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6[ (ii) the Manager of the Railway;]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g) "Railway Provident Fund" means a Provident Fund constituted by the authority of 7[ the railway] administration for any class or classes of its employees.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Protection of compulsory deposits</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3.(1) A compulsory deposit in any Government or Railway Provident Fund shall not in any way be capable of being assigned or charged and shall not be liable to attachment under any decree or order of any Civil, Revenue or Criminal Court in respect of any debt or liability incurred by the subscriber or depositor, and neither the Official Assignee nor any receiver appointed under the 8[ * * *] Insolvency Act, 1920, shall be entitled to, or have any claim on, such compulsory deposit.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Any sum standing to the credit of any subscriber to, or depositor in, any such Fund at the time of his decease and payable under the rules of the Fund to any dependant of the subscriber or depositor, or to such person as may be authorised by law to receive payment on his behalf, shall, subject to any deduction authorised by this Act and, save where the dependant is the widow or child of the subscriber or depositor, subject also to the rights of an assignee under an assignment made before the commencement of this Act, vest in the dependant, and shall, subject as aforesaid, be free from any debt or other liability incurred by the debased or incurred by the dependant before the death of the subscriber or depositor.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Provisions regarding repayments</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4.(1) When under the rules of any Government or Railway Provident Fund the sum standing to the credit of any subscriber or depositor, or the balance thereof after the making of any deduction authorised by this Act, has become payable, the officer, whose duty it is to make the payment shall pay the sum or balance, as the case may be, to the subscriber or depositor, or, if he is dead, shall -</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) if the sum or balance, or any part thereof, vests in a dependant under the provisions of section 3, pay the same to the dependant or to such person as may be authorised by law to receive payment on his behalf; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) if the whole sum or balance, as the case may be, does not exceed five thousand 9[ Taka], pay the same, or any part thereof, which is not payable under clause (a), to any person nominated to receive it under the rules of the Fund, or, if no person is so nominated, to any person appearing to him to be otherwise entitled to receive it; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) in the case of any sum or balance, or any part thereof, which is not payable to any person under clause (a). or clause (b) pay the same,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) to any person nominated to receive it under the rules of the Fund, on production by such person of probate or letters of administration evidencing the grant to him of administration to the estate of the deceased or a certificate granted under the 10[ Succession Act, 1925,] entitling the holder thereof to receive payment of such sum, balance or part, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii) where no person is so nominated, to any person who produces such probate, letters or certificate:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that, where the whole or any part of any sum standing to the credit of the subscriber or depositor has been assigned to any other person before the commencement of this Act, and notice in writing of the assignment has been received by the officer from the assignee, the officer shall, after making any deduction authorised by this Act and any payment due under clause (a) to or on behalf of the widow or children of the subscriber or depositor -</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) if the subscriber or depositor or, if he is dead the person to whom in the absence of any valid, assignment the sum or balance would be payable under this sub-section gives his consent in writing, pay the sum or part or the balance thereof, as the case may be, to the assignee, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii) if such consent is not forthcoming, withhold payment of the sum, part or balance, as the case may be, pending a decision of a competent Civil Court as to the person entitled to receive it.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2)        The making of any payment authorised by sub-section (1) shall be a full discharge to the Government or the railway administration, as the case may be, from all liability in respect of so much of the sum standing to the credit of the subscriber or depositor as is equivalent to the amount so paid.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Rights of nominees</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5.(1) Notwithstanding anything contained in any law for the time being in force or in any disposition, whether testamentary or otherwise, by a subscriber to, or depositor in, a Government or Railway Provident Fund of the sum standing to his credit in the fund, or of any part thereof, where any nomination duly made in accordance with the rules of the Fund, purports to confer upon any person the right to receive the whole or any part of such sum on the death of the subscriber or depositor occurring before the sum has become payable or before the sum. having become payable, been paid, the said person shall on the death as aforesaid of the subscriber of depositor, become entitled, to the exclusion of all other persons, to receive such sum or part thereof, as case may be, unless -</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) such nomination is at any time varied by another nomination made in like manner or expressly cancelled by notice given in the manner and to the authority prescribed by those rules, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) such nomination at any time becomes invalid by reason of the happening of some contingency specified therein, -</p><p style="text-align: justify;">and if the said person predeceases the subscriber or depositor, the nomination shall, so far as it relates to the right conferred upon the said person, become void and of no effect:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that where provision has been duly made in the nomination in accordance with the rules of the fund, conferring upon some other person such right in the stead of the person deceased, such right shall, upon the decease as aforesaid of the said person, pass to such other person.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Notwithstanding anything contained in the 11[ Succession Act, 1925], any person, who becomes entitled as aforesaid, may be granted a certificate under that Act 12[ * * *] entitling him to receive payment of such or part, and such certificate shall not be deemed to be invalidated or superseded by any grant to any other of person of probate or letters of administration to the estate of the deceased.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The provisions of this section as amended by sub-section (1) of section 2 of the Provident funds (Amendment) Act, 1946, shall apply also to all such nominations made before the date of the commencement of that Act:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the provisions of this section as so amended shall not operate to affect any case, in which before the said date any sum has paid, or has under the rules of the Fund become payable in pursuance of any nomination duly made in accordance with those rules.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power makes deductions</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. When the sum standing to the credit of any subscriber or depositor in any Government or Railway Provident Fund which is contributory Provident Fund becomes payable, there may, if the authority specified in this behalf in the rules of the Fund so directs, be deducted therefrom and paid to Government or the Railway Administration, as the case may be,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) any amount due under a liability incurred by the subscriber or depositor to Government or the Railway Administration, but not exceeding in any case the total amount of any contributions credited to the account of the subscriber or depositor and of any interest or increment which has accrued on such contributions; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        where the subscriber or depositor has been dismissed from his employment for any reasons specified in this behalf in the rules of the Fund, or where he has resigned such employment within five years of the commencement thereof, the whole or any part of the amount of any such contributions, interest and increment.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Protection for acts done in good faith</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. No suit or other legal proceeding shall lie against any person in respect of anything which is in good faith done or intended to be done under this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><b>Power to apply the act to the Provident Funds</b></p><p style="text-align: justify;">8.(1) the Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, direct that provisions of this Act shall apply to any Provident Fund established for the benefit of its employees by any local authority within the meaning of the Local Authorities Loans Act, 1914, and, on the making of such declaration, this Act shall apply accordingly, as if such Provident Fund were Government Provident Fund and such local authority were the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, direct that the provisions of this Act shall apply to any Provident Fund established for the benefit of the employees of any of the institutions specified in the Schedule, or of any group of such institutions, and, on the making of such declaration, this Act shall apply accordingly, as if such Provident Fund were a Government Provident Fund and the authority having custody of the Fund were the Government:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that section 6 shall apply as if the authority making the contributions referred to in that section were the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, add to the Schedule the name of any public institution it may deem fit, and any such addition shall take effect as if had been made by this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">13[ * * *]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[Omitted]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. [Omitted by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[Repealed]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. [Repealed by section 2 and Schedule of the Repealing Act, 1927 (Act No. XII of 1927).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">_____________________________________________</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 Throughout this Act, except otherwise provided, the words “Bangladesh” and `Government` were substituted, for the words “Pakistan” and “Central Government” or “appropriate Government” respectively by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 The words `the Government` were substituted, for the words and commas `the Secretary of State, the Central Government, the Crown Representative or any Provincial Government` by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4 The words `and references in this Act to the Government shall be construed accordingly` were omitted by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5 Sub-clause (i) was omitted by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6 Sub-clause (ii) was substituted, for the former sub-clause (ii) by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7 The words `the railway` were substituted, for letter and word `a railway` by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8 The word `Provincial` was omitted by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the Bangladesh Laws (Revision And Declaration) Act, 1973 (Act No. VIII of 1973)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9 The word `Taka` was substituted, for `Succession Act, 1925,` were substituted, for the words, commas and words `Succession Certificate Act, 1889, or under the Bombay Regulation VIII of 1827,` by section 3 and 2nd Schedule of the
